required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 13, 2016
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Calcium Retention as Influenced by Dietary Components That Induce an Acid Load
clinical_study.official_title: Calcium Retention in Postmenopausal Women as Influenced by Beef and Other Dietary Components That Induce an Acid Load
clinical_study.source: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: The impact of protein sources such as beef as part of Western diet on calcium retention remains controversial. We propose to test the hypothesis that the positive effect of high protein intake (especially from meat protein) can offset the negative effect of protein-induced net acid load on bone metabolism and the retention of body calcium. Healthy postmenopausal women recruited from the community will consume two diets differing in meat protein and acid load for 7 weeks. Calcium retention from diets will be determined using a highly sensitive measurement of whole body retention of a calcium isotope added to the diet.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Bio-availability Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Prevention

primary_outcome.description: After 3 weeks equilibration to the diet, the 2-day menu was extrinsically labeled with Calcium-47 radiotracer and retention was monitored for 28 days by whole body scintillation counting. Percent Calcium-47 absorbed was estimated from the y-intercept of the linear portion of a semilogarithmic plot of percent Calcium-47 retained vs time.

arm_group.description: Dietary Intervention: High meat and high acid load diet followed by low meat and low acid load diet
Dietary Intervention: Low meat and low acid load diet followed by high meat and high acid load diet

intervention.intervention_name: High Meat - High Potential Renal Acid Load (PRAL) diet
Low Protein - Low Potential Renal Acid Load (PRAL) diet

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Average body mass index
- Normal blood work
- Normal bone density
Exclusion Criteria:
- Chronic disorder
- Non-traumatic bone fractures

overall_official.affiliation: USDA Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

facility.name: United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

reference.citation: Roughead ZK, Johnson LK, Lykken GI, Hunt JR. Controlled high meat diets do not affect calcium retention or indices of bone status in healthy postmenopausal women. J Nutr. 2003 Apr;133(4):1020-6.

responsible_party.organization: United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were recruited from the Grand Forks, North Dakota community in November and December, 2007.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Of the 128 women who applied for the study, 56 did not meet the criteria, 46 declined, 4 were alternates, and 22 joined the study.

group.title: High Meat & High Potential Renal Acid Load - First
group.description: High meat and high potential renal acid load (high PRAL) diet followed by low meat and low potential renal acid load (low PRAL) diet.

group.title: Low Meat & Low Potential Renal Acid Load - First
group.description: Low meat and low potential renal acid load (low PRAL) followed by High meat and high potential renal acid load (high PRAL) diet.

group.title: Entire Study Population
group.description: Dietary Intervention: Crossover design, High meat and high potential renal acid load (high PRAL) diet and low meat and low potential renal acid load (low PRAL) diet, consumed in random order.

outcome.title: Calcium Absorption
outcome.description: After 3 weeks equilibration to the diet, the 2-day menu was extrinsically labeled with Calcium-47 radiotracer and retention was monitored for 28 days by whole body scintillation counting. Percent Calcium-47 absorbed was estimated from the y-intercept of the linear portion of a semilogarithmic plot of percent Calcium-47 retained vs time.
outcome.population: Analysis included only the 16 volunteers that completed both dietary interventions.

group.title: High Meat - High Potential Renal Acid Load
group.description: High meat and high potential renal acid load (high PRAL) diet in either the first or second intervention period

group.title: Low Meat - Low Potential Renal Acid Load
group.description: Low meat and low potential renal acid load (low PRAL) diet in either the first or second intervention period

measure.title: Calcium Absorption
measure.description: After 3 weeks equilibration to the diet, the 2-day menu was extrinsically labeled with Calcium-47 radiotracer and retention was monitored for 28 days by whole body scintillation counting. Percent Calcium-47 absorbed was estimated from the y-intercept of the linear portion of a semilogarithmic plot of percent Calcium-47 retained vs time.

analysis.groups_desc: 16 subjects required to detect a difference in Calcium 47 absorption of 2 percentage points with 90% power, alpha = 0.05
analysis.method_desc: Mixed model analysis of variance tested for treatment and feeding sequence effects.

group.title: High Meat & High Potential Renal Acid Load - First
group.description: High meat and high potential renal acid load (high PRAL) diet followed by low meat and low potential renal acid load (low PRAL) diet.

group.title: Low Meat & Low Potential Renal Acid Load - First
group.description: Low meat and low potential renal acid load (low PRAL) followed by High meat and high potential renal acid load (high PRAL) diet.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

point_of_contact.organization: United States Department of Agriculture Grand Forks Human Nutrition Research Center
